abstract: <jats:p>Genomewide association studies (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content>) and candidate‐gene studies have implicated single‐nucleotide polymorphisms (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s) in at least 45 different genes as putative glioma risk factors. Attempts to validate these associations have yielded variable results and few genetic risk factors have been consistently replicated. We conducted a case‐control study of Caucasian glioma cases and controls from the University of California San Francisco (810 cases, 512 controls) and the Mayo Clinic (852 cases, 789 controls) in an attempt to replicate previously reported genetic risk factors for glioma. Sixty <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s selected from the literature (eight from <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content> and 52 from candidate‐gene studies) were successfully genotyped on an <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">I</jats:styled-content>llumina custom genotyping panel. Eight <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s in/near seven different genes (<jats:italic>TERT</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>EGFR</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>CCDC26</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>CDKN2A</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>PHLDB1</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>RTEL1</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>) were significantly associated with glioma risk in the combined dataset (<jats:italic>P</jats:italic> < 0.05), with all associations in the same direction as in previous reports. Several <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> associations showed considerable differences across histologic subtype. All eight successfully replicated associations were first identified by <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content>, although none of the putative risk <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s from candidate‐gene studies was associated in the full case‐control sample (all <jats:italic>P</jats:italic> values > 0.05). Although several confirmed associations are located near genes long known to be involved in gliomagenesis (e.g., <jats:italic>EGFR</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>CDKN2A</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>), these associations were first discovered by the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content> approach and are in noncoding regions. These results highlight that the deficiencies of the candidate‐gene approach lay in selecting both appropriate genes and relevant <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s within these genes.</jats:p>

title: Analysis of 60 Reported Glioma Risk <scp>SNP</scp>s Replicates Published <scp>GWAS</scp> Findings but Fails to Replicate Associations From Published Candidate‐Gene Studies
